brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this research is to determine whether varying the energy density and portion
      size of the main course will affect meal energy intake after consumption of a first course
      that has previously been shown to enhance satiety. It is hypothesized that increasing either
      the energy density or portion size of the main course will increase meal energy intake after
      consumption of the first course. It is also hypothesized that compared to when a first
      course is consumed, not consuming a first course will increase meal energy intake.

clinical_study.brief_title: Varying the Energy Density and Portion Size of the Main Course After a First-course Salad

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Adults from Penn State and the surrounding community

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Currently dieting

          -  Food allergies

intervention.description: In a crossover design, adults are served breakfast and lunch, 1 day a week for 6 weeks. Breakfast is not varied across weeks. At 4 of the lunch meals, a salad first course will be served that needs to be eaten in its entirety. At these 4 meals the lunch entree will vary in energy density (100% and 133%) and portion size (100% and 133%). At the 2 lunch meals for which no first course is served, the lunch entree will be vary in energy density (100% and 133%) but be the same portion size (133%).
intervention.intervention_name: Energy density and portion size feeding study

facility.name: The Pennsylvania State University, Laboratory for the Study of Human Ingestive Behavior

clinical_study.official_title: Varying the Energy Density and Portion Size of the Main Course After a First-course Salad

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor of Nutritional Sciences and Director of the Laboratory for the Study of Ingestive Behavior

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Prevention
